class_notes:
(Same as MESAS 370 5 and WGS 385 4) 
Few symbols in today's world are as laden and fraught as sharia, an Arabic-origin term referring to the straight path, the path God revealed for humans, the norms and rules guiding Muslims on that path, and Islamic law and normativity. Yet the ways Muslim men and women experience the myriad dimensions of sharia often go unnoticed and unpublicized, as do the everyday lives of 'ordinary Muslims.' 
This course aims to help ameliorate this situation by exploring the life experiences of an important cross-section of the world's ordinary Muslims in both Muslim-majority nations and the West (especially the U.S.). More specifically, the course examines how anthropologists have approached the study of Muslim cultures and politics and what we have learned from their scholarship about 'everyday Islam,' piety, race, music, popular culture, law, and social justice, with particular reference to the transnational Palestinian LGBTQ social movement and issues of gender variance and same-sex relations in the Middle East and Southeast Asia.
